clinical_study.brief_title: Dual Rapid HIV & Syphilis Tests in Zambia
clinical_study.official_title: Field Performance Evaluation of Dual Rapid HIV & Syphilis Tests in Zambia

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to provide evidence on the performance and operational characteristics of commercially available dual HIV/syphilis Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) in Zambia for their introduction into antenatal care and other settings.

detailed_description.textblock:
Early detection and timely intervention of pregnant women infected with HIV and/or syphilis is critical. To improve the number of women tested and treated, the Centre for Infectious Disease Research in Zambia (CIDRZ) and the Ministry of Community Development, Mother and Health (MCDMCH) this field study will assess the effectiveness of newly developed dual HIV and syphilis rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) manufactured by Chembio and Standard Diagnostics in Lusaka District antenatal clinics.
The specific objectives of this field performance evaluation of the rapid diagnostics are to determine the antenatal clinic-based performance of dual HIV/syphilis RDTs compared to that of current reference standard assays, and to assess the operational characteristics and acceptability of these dual HIV/syphilis RDTs to patients and health care providers This cross-sectional study of 3,765 pregnant women will validate the performance of Chembio and Standard Diagnostics dual HIV and Syphilis RDTs.

primary_outcome.measure: performance of dual rapid HIV/syphilis tests
primary_outcome.description: The performance of the rapid study tests will be assessed by determining the specificity and the sensitivity when compared to reference standard assays

secondary_outcome.measure: acceptability of use of dual rapid HIV/syphilis tests
secondary_outcome.description: the operational characteristics and acceptability of the tests to patients and health care providers will be measured.

arm_group.description: Pregnant women, regardless of HIV status, seeking antenatal care at clinics in Lusaka, Zambia

study_pop.textblock: Pregnant women, regardless of HIV status, seeking antenatal care at Chipata, Chawama, or Kamwala District Health Centres in Lusaka, Zambia.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women attending their first antenatal care visit at a study clinic
- 18 years of age or older
- Willing and able to provide informed consent for study participation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Prior participation in the study
